001package squidpony.squidmath;
002
003/**
004 * An interface for "point hashes", that is, functions that produce usually-unique integer results given multiple
005 * integer inputs. The hash functions this guarantees an implementor will provide all take int inputs and return an int.
006 * There are lots of cases where an implementor would have other functions that take long inputs or return longs, and in
007 * those cases the interface methods would probably be implemented by delegating to the long inputs and/or casting the
008 * result to a long. Implementors must have a {@link #setState(int)} function, but it doesn't have to do anything if the
009 * algorithm doesn't support a state; similarly, {@link #hashWithState(int, int, int)} can return the same thing as
010 * {@link #hash(int, int)} if states aren't supported. If states are supported, then calling {@link #hash(int, int)}
011 * while the state is, for example, 42 should be the same as calling {@link #hashWithState(int, int, int)} with a state
012 * parameter of 42 (regardless of what the state actually is in the implementor).
013 * <br>
014 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 4/13/2020.
015 */
016public interface IPointHash {
017    void setState(int state);
018    int hash(int x, int y);
019    int hash(int x, int y, int z);
020    int hash(int x, int y, int z, int w);
021    int hash(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u);
022    int hash(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v);
023    int hashWithState(int x, int y, int state);
024    int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int state);
025    int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int w, int state);
026    int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int state);
027    int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v, int state);
028
029    /**
030     * A convenience abstract class to implement IPointHash when you have an int for state. Subclasses will need to
031     * implement {@link #hashWithState(int, int, int)},  {@link #hashWithState(int, int, int, int)},
032     * {@link #hashWithState(int, int, int, int, int)}, and  {@link #hashWithState(int, int, int, int, int, int, int)}.
033     * They can optionally override {@link #setState(int)}, and can at their discretion provide an accessor for the
034     * protected int {@link #state}.
035     */
036    abstract class IntImpl implements IPointHash {
037        protected int state = 42;
038        public IntImpl(){
039        }
040        public IntImpl(int state){
041            this.state = state;
042        }
043
044        @Override
045        public void setState(int state) {
046            this.state = state;
047        }
048
049        @Override
050        public int hash(int x, int y) {
051            return hashWithState(x, y, state);
052        }
053
054        @Override
055        public int hash(int x, int y, int z) {
056            return hashWithState(x, y, z, state);
057        }
058
059        @Override
060        public int hash(int x, int y, int z, int w) {
061            return hashWithState(x, y, z, w, state);
062        }
063
064        @Override
065        public int hash(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u) {
066            return hashWithState(x, y, z, w, u, state);
067        }
068
069        @Override
070        public int hash(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v) {
071            return hashWithState(x, y, z, w, u, v, state);
072        }
073    }
074    /**
075     * A convenience abstract class to implement IPointHash when you have a long for state. Subclasses will need to
076     * implement {@link #hashWithState(int, int, int)},  {@link #hashWithState(int, int, int, int)},
077     * {@link #hashWithState(int, int, int, int, int)}, {@link #hashWithState(int, int, int, int, int, int)}, an
078     * {@link #hashWithState(int, int, int, int, int, int, int)}.
079     * They can optionally override {@link #setState(int)} or {@link #setState(long)}, and can at their discretion
080     * provide an accessor for the protected long {@link #state}.
081     */
082    abstract class LongImpl implements IPointHash {
083        protected long state = 42;
084        public LongImpl(){
085            setState(42);
086        }
087        public LongImpl(int state){
088            setState(state);
089        }
090        public LongImpl(long state){
091            setState(state);
092        }
093
094        @Override
095        public void setState(int state) {
096            this.state = state;
097        }
098        
099        public void setState(long state){
100            this.state = state;
101        }
102
103        @Override
104        public int hash(int x, int y) {
105            return hashWithState(x, y, (int) (state ^ state >>> 32));
106        }
107
108        @Override
109        public int hash(int x, int y, int z) {
110            return hashWithState(x, y, z, (int) (state ^ state >>> 32));
111        }
112
113        @Override
114        public int hash(int x, int y, int z, int w) {
115            return hashWithState(x, y, z, w, (int) (state ^ state >>> 32));
116        }
117
118        @Override
119        public int hash(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u) {
120            return hashWithState(x, y, z, w, u, (int) (state ^ state >>> 32));
121        }
122        @Override
123        public int hash(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v) {
124            return hashWithState(x, y, z, w, u, v, (int) (state ^ state >>> 32));
125        }
126    }
127}
